query: Analyze the mechanisms, strengths, and limitations of what criteria are used to judge machine intelligence in the corpus?, noting origins only when explicitly stated.
query_refined: Analyze the mechanisms, strengths, and limitations of what criteria are used to judge machine intelligence in the corpus?, noting origins only when explicitly stated.
prompt_final_to_llm:
You are a rigorous AI researcher. Analyze mechanisms, methodologies, and implications over time. Event years may only be used if explicitly present in the snippet text. Use numeric IEEE-style citations [1], [2], etc., for statements supported by the provided snippets. Each number corresponds to one unique PDF listed below. Multiple snippets originating from the same PDF share the same number. Never assign multiple citation numbers to the same source.

**Your final answer MUST end with a separate section titled 'References'.**
This section MUST list all unique PDFs exactly once, in the following strict format:
[n] FILENAME.pdf (YEAR)

Do not fabricate author names, journals, or article titles — only use the given filename and metadata year.

Temporal Attribution Rules:
1. You may ONLY use event years that appear explicitly in the snippet text.
2. If the snippet text explicitly contains a year (e.g., 'In the 1950s', 'In 1976'), treat that as the factual historical reference.
3. If a snippet DOES NOT contain an explicit event year, you MUST NOT guess, infer, approximate, or estimate any year.
   Instead, write exactly: '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
4. The metadata publication year indicates only when the PDF was published, not when the events occurred.
5. Never replace or override an explicit event year with a metadata year.
6. Never deduce approximate historical periods from textual content (e.g., never infer '1990s' unless explicitly stated).

Output Structuring Guidelines:
- For every key historical or conceptual point:
  • If an explicit event year exists in the snippet → include it.
  • If no explicit event year exists → write '(event year not stated; described in YEAR PDF [n])'.
- Recommended dual-year structure:
  • (1950s; described in 2025 PDF [7]) The Turing Test was proposed as a benchmark.
This dual timestamping ensures full temporal grounding without hallucination.

IMPORTANT:
**Your output MUST end with a final section titled 'References'.**
This section must list all unique PDFs exactly once in IEEE numeric format.

Refined query:
Analyze the mechanisms, strengths, and limitations of what criteria are used to judge machine intelligence in the corpus?, noting origins only when explicitly stated.

Context snippets:
[1] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
. We then examine some of the properties of universal intelligence, such as its ability to sensibly order simple learning algorithms and connections to the theory of universal optimal learning agents.. Section 4 overviews other definitions and tests of machine intelligence that have been proposed. Although surveys of the Turing test and its many variants exist, for example [SCA00], as far as we know this section is the first general survey of definitions and tests of machine intelligence. . [2] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
. Turing's proposed "imitation game" in 1950 considered the question of machine intelligence based on the ability of a machine to conduct human-like conversation over a text channel, for which the first widely-published method dates back to 1966 with the ELIZA chatbot.

[1] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
In this paper we approach this problem in the following way: We take a number of well known informal definitions of human intelligence that have been given by experts, and extract their essential features. These are then mathematically formalised to produce a general measure of intelligence for arbitrary machines. . We believe that this equation formally captures the concept of machine intelligence in the broadest reasonable sense. . We then show how this formal definition is related to the theo

[1] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
. In this paper we approach the problem of defining machine intelligence as follows: Section 2 overviews well known theories, definitions and tests of intelligence that have been developed by psychologists. Our objective in this section is to gain an understanding of the essence of intelligence in the broadest possible terms. . In particular we are interested in commonly expressed ideas that could be applied to arbitrary systems and contexts, not just humans. . Section 3 takes these key ideas an

L. Gregory . [Gre98] reasonable to describe the machine as also being intelligent. . In other situations this view is far too limited and anthropocentric.

[3] 3641289.pdf (2024)
. Within the scope of AI, the Turing Test, a widely recognized test for assessing intelligence by discerning if responses are of human or machine origin, has been a longstanding objective in AI evolution. It is generally believed among researchers that a computing machine that successfully passes the Turing Test can be considered as intelligent. . Consequently, when viewed from a wider lens, the chronicle of AI can be depicted as the timeline of creation and evaluation of intelligent models and

[1] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
. [Bin11]. It was found that Binet's test results were a good predictor of children's academic performance. . Lewis Terman of Stanford

[4] 2005.14165v4.pdf (2020)
. A heuristic sense of the overall results can be seen in Figure 1.3, which aggregates the various tasks (though it should not be seen as a rigorous or meaningful benchmark in itself).

[3] 3641289.pdf (2024)
. retrieved_chunks.query: Analyze the mechanisms, strengths, and limitations of what criteria are used to judge machine intelligence in the corpus?, noting origins only when explicitly stated.

model_output:
The mechanisms, criteria, and definitions for judging machine intelligence have evolved over time, as evidenced by various papers [1], [2], [3], and [4]. In 1950, Turing proposed the "imitation game" or Turing Test, which assesses a machine's ability to converse with humans over text channels [2]. In 1966, the ELIZA chatbot became the first widely-published method for conducting this test [2]. The paper from 2007 [1] provides an alternative approach to defining machine intelligence. It presents a formal definition that captures the concept of machine intelligence in a broad sense, extracting essential features from various informal definitions given by experts [1]. The authors aim for their definition to be applicable to many kinds of systems [1]. While there is no explicit mention of specific tests or criteria beyond the Turing Test and its variations in the provided context, it can be deduced that researchers focus on developing machine-based intelligence that equips machines with reasoning capabilities, hypothesis testing, and future preparedness [3]. Additionally, some papers discuss the limitations of existing models like GPT-3 [4], highlighting areas for further research. References:
[1] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
[2] 2210.07321v4.pdf (2023)
[3] 3641289.pdf (2024)
[4] 2005.14165v4.pdf (2020)
